The failure is as much of teachers and experts as it is of businesses and politicians.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555445334000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12826250', u'id': u'128128562', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'Scientific paradigms change when there is sufficient evidence that the paradigm cannot explain.
Climate science is based on a vast mass of evidence, from research done in dozens of countries.
Tens of thousands of pieces of research in geochemistry, palaeontology, oceanography, atmospheric physics, and many more fields of study, starting in the 19th century, have resulted in this overall concept.
In fact, climate change is probably the most scrutinised area of science ever, and the current scientific position meets the standards of other scientific paradigms like evolution, plate tectonics, and relativity.
Of course it can't predict every short-term fluctuation, any more than plate tectonics predicts the timing and scale of every earthquake or volcanic eruption.
Climate science is very much like plate tectonics, in that it gives an overall framework to investigations of processes in a range of earth systems.
To change the paradigm, someone would need to produce plenty of research-based evidence that does not fit the paradigm, and to offer an alternative paradigm that explains all the previous evidence plus the new evidence.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555433289000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'tens of thousands of pieces of research in geochemistry starting in the 19th century', u'effect': u'this overall concept'}], u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'128106938', u'id': u'128125629', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'CLeighton', u'text': u'The UK has turned in one of the best performances for the past decade,making it odd that this rebellion is concentrated in the UK. But it could belike other Guardian promotions, mostly political. Apparently, the UKstill has the wrong government.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555433093000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'101346019', u'in_reply_to': u'128125157', u'id': u'128125566', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Snaga', u'text': u'Ah, so the total amount is not all that matters. So you are agreeing that it makes sense to look at who is emitting the most, and presumably why they are doing it. On that basis, it makes no sense to not consider the per capita emissions.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555445308000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3060949', u'in_reply_to': u'128116473', u'id': u'128128548', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Snaga', u'text': u'There's a superficial similarity but I think that conceals more than it reveals. First of all, the referendum was won by people who apparently are prepared to forgo some GDP growth for some other gain. Really, I think the argument is about if that is a good trade-off. Remainers want open societies and collaborative relationships with our neighbours, so Brexit is a lose-lose for them. Economic pain and a cultural hit. The striking thing is how little traction the 'no one voted to be poorer' argument gets. What's the response? Fuck business, or 'its not my GDP'. I see that as a case study of how people may well accept economic pain if they think there is a benefit.
I question the assumption that people would have a worse quality of life if we tackle climate change though. I think in fact the reverse is true in two ways. Overall quality of life will improve if we protect the natural world, because our environment sustains us. And if we don't do it, we will face sacrifices on an appalling scale. It is essential we make this argument, and do so now.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555444903000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'our environment sustains us', u'effect': u'overall quality of life will improve if we protect the natural world'}], u'author_id': u'3060949', u'in_reply_to': u'128111064', u'id': u'128128449', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'The UK Climate Change Committee that advises the government says that by 2025 we need to stop connecting new buildings to the gas grid.
Space heating is one of the more difficult issues, but this is a start.
The Chancellor supported this policy recently.
In the long term we need to heat buildings (very well insulated buildings) differently - probably using heat pumps. Right now they are expensive, but again it's all about economies of scale.
The 2025 target, of course, doesn't address the issue of retrofitting all the existing homes and other buildings that have gas heating (& hot water)
Gas boilers, of course, have a limited life and the key is to decide what new tech should become the standard replacement at they wear out.
Heat pumps might be part of it, but there's some work being done on "mains H2" which would need a big upgrade to the infrastructure and would need hydrogen-fired boilers.
Gas mains would probably need re-lining because H2 is a smaller molecule than CH4.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555432809000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'h2 is a smaller molecule than ch4', u'effect': u'gas mains would probably need re - lining'}], u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'128125157', u'id': u'128125472', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'CLeighton', u'text': u'True, weather events in Bangladesh wouldn't matter.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555432611000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'101346019', u'in_reply_to': u'128125218', u'id': u'128125409', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'c.l. shannon', u'text': u'If that’s the plan ... a thuggish coup for “our own good” then you will find considerable pushback.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555444192000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100151035', u'in_reply_to': u'128112868', u'id': u'128128298', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'I'm still waiting to hear about the evidence you have that the global scientific community is wrong about climate change.
Are you still claiming that petition means something?', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555443752000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'128128063', u'id': u'128128187', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'EGriff', u'text': u'What exactly is the UK and the UK govt not doing to fight climate change?
We reduced our CO2 by 44% on 1990 levels, we got 33% of our electricity from renewables last year – 53% from low carbon, adding in nuclear… 
We have a massive programme of renewables building in terms of offshore wind and even a functioning tidal turbine installation… we have an end date for all coal power plants, target date for moving to all electric vehicles, plans to stop fossil fuel heating in all new housing…
We’ve built new grid infrastructure (e.g the west coast HVDC line) to ensure maximum use of renewables, there’s a plan to replace hundreds of diesel trains with hydrogen powered trains.
UK electricity demand is still falling after a decade, due to energy efficiency…
Can we do more? Certainly!
But it is not by any means that we are doing nothing or have achieved nothing!', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555432565000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4149361', u'id': u'128125396', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'The global economy needs to be carbon-neutral within around 3 decades.
By 2030 the Keeling Curve needs to be showing a lower gradient.
Economies won't function in a rebooted PETM.
The current rate of rise in CO2 is faster than during the Palaeocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum.
The fossil record in rocks formed around the equator during the PETM is really poor, and that's an indication that life in the tropics was extremely stressed.
New research:
"Temporal Scaling of Carbon Emission and Accumulation Rates: Modern Anthropogenic Emissions Compared to Estimates of PETM‐Onset Accumulation" - Gingerich, 2019
confirms, and builds on, what was already known about the PETM:
BQSTART
"The Paleocene‐Eocene thermal maximum (PETM) is a global greenhouse warming event that happened 56 million years ago, causing extinction in the world's oceans and accelerated evolution on the continents....... 
If the present trend of increasing carbon emissions continues, we may see PETM‐magnitude extinction and accelerated evolution in as few as 140 years or about five human generations.
BQEND', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555432218000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'that', u'effect': u"extinction in the world 's oceans"}], u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'128122581', u'id': u'128125287', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Alan Griffiths', u'text': u'Who Snopes the snopes :--- "" It is impossible to understate how antithetical this is to the fact checking world, in which absolute openness and transparency are necessary prerequisites for trust. Yet they give up their time to try and save you too', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555431968000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4149361', u'in_reply_to': u'128098353', u'id': u'128125177', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ElephantofTruth', u'text': u'The legal position regarding the incident with the dangerous human remains in flux. Happy to report that a number of large mammal species have joined forces, perceiving it to be of mutual benefit to act in unison vis a vis existential threats to their existence. These species however await rather trepidatiously the policy responses of a rather powerful, volatile and yet disunited mammal species that has been particularly active these last few millenia.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555441847000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4154310', u'in_reply_to': u'128127060', u'id': u'128127783', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'CO2 is involved in many of the warming events seen in the geological record.
I suggest you read about some previous warming events, like the end-Permian, the PETM, the Toarcian, and the ETM2. They are seen in the geochemical record as negative carbon isotope excursions.
These NCIEs mark sudden releases of sequestered carbon, are always associated with global warming, and with extinction events of varying severity.
At least one mass extinction is associated with lots of CO2 being formed by burning fossil fuel.
It was volcanic action that burned coal then, in Siberia.
There are a number of papers on that such as:
"Initial pulse of Siberian Traps sills as the trigger of the end-Permian mass extinction" - Burgess et al, 2017
Human societies are adapted to the recent interglacial conditions, which have been suitable for agriculture.
Rapid destabilising change is going to make tropical regions virtually unusable for farming within a century or so.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555441783000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'128122492', u'id': u'128127770', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'MazaroneofNY', u'text': u'My point is the radical action which has been demanded by the left is unfeasible, the green deal is not practical. As for left wing outlets, https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2019/feb/13/school-climate-strike-childrens-brave-stand-has-our-support from this very paper.
Shell and BP are regularly castigated by the media when they are investing huge amounts into renewable energy. Even in the US, there is appetitie for green financing at state level and within the private sector. While it was regrettable that we left the Paris deal, we cannot damage our oil and fracking industry, especially that now we are the largest oil and natural gas producers in the world as it would damage our economy. Also, the protests within the UK are pointless as they have undertaken some of the biggest reforms to cut emissions. The real reality is not friendly to the left but the EU have been contrarian in the way they deal with member states, while countries like the UK follow their environmental directives, others like Germany are given a free pass which has meant the UK's heavy industries such as steel have suffered irreparably. Only this week there were protests against a new coal mine in Cumbria that would help breach the North South divide but again the populist left want to shut it down at the expense of the economy and jobs at a time Brexit is bringing havoc on their economy. Champagne socialists have always prioritized virtue signalling over the actual needs.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555414594000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15732321', u'in_reply_to': u'128104992', u'id': u'128117246', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'AJVC1991', u'text': u'Because some countries produce significantly more than others...', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555413366000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100102208', u'in_reply_to': u'128107012', u'id': u'128116473', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, ...]
description: Editorial: Disrupting traffic is not enough – we must disrupt our progress towards climate catastrophe
og_fields.og:description: Editorial: Disrupting traffic is not enough – we must disrupt our progress towards climate catastrophe
og_fields.og:title: The Guardian view on Extinction Rebellion: one small step | Editorial
text:
The planned choking of traffic in central London on Monday by climate activists of Extinction Rebellion falls somewhere between street theatre and direct action. If it is successful it will be costly for the demonstrators, some of whom plan to be arrested, burdensome for bus passengers who can’t get to work, and vexing for car drivers who (unlike those in emergency vehicles) will be held up. And yet, should it fail, the long-term costs of climate change will be immense for almost everybody now alive and for all our descendents, too.
In the short term, the rage of the frustrated motorist remains one of the most powerful political forces in countries like ours. The gilets jaunes movement in France started off in part as a protest against price rises on petrol; the Blair government sustained its first big defeat at the hands of lorry drivers in the fuel protests of 2000, which destroyed a sensible and ecologically necessary plan to raise fuel taxes steadily over time to discourage the use of fossil fuels.
Any movement towards ecological sanity will have to confront this anger. The drivers’ blockades were effective direct action in support of the destruction of the planet. The challenge today is to find means of direct action that work towards its preservation while winning the same kind of social acceptance and political force.
The idea that we can change the whole basis of our planetary economy without pain and inconvenience for the global middle classes is simply false. The enormous political challenge is to ensure that the pain of adjustment towards a carbon-neutral economy is fairly distributed. At the moment the pain is concentrated on those least able to bear it. This is true between countries, in as much as it is sub-Saharan Africa where the destabilising effects of climate change are most visible and painful. It is also true within the rich countries which consume more than they sustainably can. In the west it is the poor who will be hit worst by rising prices for food and fuel. Yet a future of less consumption and less convenience is inevitable. We can choose to some extent how and when to face it, but it cannot be indefinitely postponed.
The purpose of climate activism is to make that choice consciously and deliberately, with planning and forethought, rather than have it forced upon us in a series of improvisations between catastrophes. The activists of Extinction Rebellion use the metaphor of war, and this is not entirely exaggerated. Although one of the purposes of groups like Extinction Rebellion is to avert wars over resources, this may – paradoxically – require the kind of social and political mobilisation only otherwise seen in wartime. The sense of a common purpose, and of suffering borne in common, which has so often and so fraudulently been invoked in the rhetoric of the political right since the financial crisis must now be appropriated and given real meaning.
Yet it is not enough for climate change to remain solely a cause of the left. This is a cause that must ultimately transcend left-right distinctions. To achieve such an escape from traditional politics will not be easy. It will be fiercely resisted, because there are many powerful forces that benefit, in the short term, from smugness and inaction. But the movement needs to isolate and expose them.
The protests are intended as the start of a global movement, as they must be. By themselves, they will accomplish little. Yet the longest journey begins with the first step – even if this is the step taken by a driver who climbs out of their gridlocked car and tries to find some other way of continuing their journey.

I disagree.
Over the last 20-30 years we have seen many attempts at education surrounding climate change where those attempts have had huge world wide coverage..
A few examples for you.
1. David Attenborough has done many documentaries that have charted the way that climate change is changing the planet. One he did was called Are We Changing Planet Earth?  which was filmed over 10 years ago in 2006.
Another one he did was called State of the planet and was released around 20 years ago.
2. Al Gore has played a major global role in raising awareness of the dangers of climate change since his 2007 film An Inconvenient TruthAn Inconvenient TruthAn Inconvenient Truth.
3. NASA has repeatedly released photos of the melting ice caps. They have even released time laps photos of the melting ice caps. The first images I remember seeing personally was on the news back in the late 1980s.
4. The number of news articles that we have seen on climate change over the last 30 or so years is not small by any means. The number of times we have seen freak weather events reported where the news has claimed that climate change is increasing the frequency of the these events is also not small by any means.
5. According to some sources climate change is already being taught in schools as the following quote points out
BQSTART
Geography teachers will rightly point to the unequivocal requirements within the geography national curriculum and its GCSE and A level specifications that pupils learn about our climate and how it has changed – alongside wider environmental and ecological issues.
BQEND
https://www.tes.com/news/climate-change-already-taught-schools
The films that two individuals I have mentioned have made have had global coverage and yet here we are with some people still claiming that education is what is needed.
I could find many more examples of high profile figures that have made films around climate change than just these two.
Now if the high profile figures that I have mentioned here have not managed to turn education around climate change into action what practical use is handing out a few leaflets going to achieve?
Our own government have a woeful record on tackling climate change. Despite the fact that it is one of the most pressing issues facing our own country and the wider world at large the number of debates that our own government have had on the issue over the last 6-10 years has been staggeringly bad.
If our democratically elected representatives who are supposed to be amongst the most educated people in our country are willing to sweep this issue under the carpet then how on earth is more education going to help?
I would argue that it is not education that we need as most people have at least a basic understanding that climate change is going to have a huge effect on us all. Most people are fully aware that runaway climate change has the potential to wipe out our species.
What we really need is positive action to tackle climate change. We need to force our governments to take the needed action to tackle the issue rather than allow them to sweep it under the carpet. More education is not going to ensure that our government gets off its backside and deals with the issue.', u'recommendation_count': u'19', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555351011000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10085855', u'in_reply_to': u'128093553', u'id': u'128096823', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'mf m', u'text': u'What's your suggestion?', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555350297000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100368422', u'in_reply_to': u'128094146', u'id': u'128096547', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'OnMeBiker', u'text': u'Irony. *no, there isn't going to be an electric car for everyone.', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555350826000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16171854', u'in_reply_to': u'128096388', u'id': u'128096753', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Matthew2012', u'text': u'And if it were 100% of them what is your point. And BTW you could still have a very significant carbon footprint even if your transport emissions are low.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555350194000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10230223', u'in_reply_to': u'128095729', u'id': u'128096495', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'BrexitHereWeCome', u'text': u'" I used to buy 3 crates of water a week,"
With a thought process like that, I'm not surprised you ended up in poverty.', u'recommendation_count': u'20', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555350173000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16909885', u'in_reply_to': u'128096306', u'id': u'128096487', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'Increasingly, from huge windfarms, and they are also installing more solar than any other country.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555349610000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'128096104', u'id': u'128096269', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Forlornehope', u'text': u'I don't have any!', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555349584000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3222870', u'in_reply_to': u'128094228', u'id': u'128096259', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Hegelsdog', u'text': u'Thank you, officer. Mind how you go.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555350766000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16509449', u'in_reply_to': u'128096350', u'id': u'128096728', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'KatieL', u'text': u'"How do you know they didn’t bike, walk or use public transport?"
Does public transport not use fuel? Is manufacturing bikes carbon-free? And if they walked, did their breakfast walk to their table before they ate it?', u'recommendation_count': u'18', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555350735000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2676750', u'in_reply_to': u'128096593', u'id': u'128096714', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Tom Archer', u'text': u'Love it! Let them pioneer a zero emission life style and show the rest of us how its done!', u'recommendation_count': u'18', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555348950000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12103643', u'in_reply_to': u'128094256', u'id': u'128096008', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DriverOfTheNorth', u'text': u'Most people don't like protests because they are fearful their own miserable short term existence will be affected. It's just the 'I'm alright Jack' attitude surfacing like it surfaces in every other aspect of government policy that doesn't affect them directly. Benefit cuts for the disabled? No problem, I'm not disabled. Climate change? No problem, I doesn't seem to affect me yet.
If there is one thing as sure as life and death. It is that people will be selfish until death knocks on their doors.', u'recommendation_count': u'17', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555350158000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'they are fearful their own miserable short term existence will be affected', u'effect': u"most people do n't like protests"}], u'author_id': u'17686763', u'id': u'128096477', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bolldamm', u'text': u'Try this too:
https://rationalwiki.org/wiki/Guy_McPherson', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555350147000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13938188', u'in_reply_to': u'128094034', u'id': u'128096474', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ByzantineSailor', u'text': u'Aeons ago when a student I got arrested for damaging police property (nothing damaged actually), and slapped around in the police station. They cautioned me, and in the shared student digs I lived in, later on I pinned up the caution note along with the other totems of student rebellion.
Later on, a police drugs bust occurred early one morning and the DS (disguised by wearing denim jeans) were amused to see that I was clearly a criminal marijuana user and urban terrorist. There was 9 g amongst 4 people who were arrested and arraigned in the County Court.
I found time in the cells was easily negotiated by doing yoga headstands and suchlike, and endorse this stratagem for anyone else so temporarily restrained.
You had to refuse that they take fingerprints and they had to get a court order, which they never got round to in those days, though in order to justify their existence now in our police state I guess this could have changed and DNA tests taken, which of course is worse than fingerprints.
My experience of the law taught me not to get  stuffing the police state, and that the police are lazy, inefficient, and stupid.
Still rebelling 45 years later, and we predicted climate change 45 years ago. The slimy profiteers march on however, we have a clear conscience.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555349583000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'101434024', u'id': u'128096258', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'tomwisemanclarke', u'text': u'It’s easy to criticise.', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555349524000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13550122', u'id': u'128096240', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Knowles2', u'text': u'Buying shares in companies like shell and then force shareholder voted to replace board directors with people who want to fight climate change.
Make sure their pensions are being invested in companies and infrastructure that is kinder to the environment.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555350719000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3726027', u'in_reply_to': u'128095735', u'id': u'128096704', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'zavaell', u'text': u'But he's right, you have to admit.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555350697000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1347038', u'in_reply_to': u'128096573', u'id': u'128096696', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'britlib', u'text': u'Yep...Just the usual bunch of middle-class kids on an ego trip', u'recommendation_count': u'43', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555348949000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3621691', u'in_reply_to': u'128095947', u'id': u'128096007', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'matthinc', u'text': u'Ben, we need a plurality of approaches. I don't think it's particularly useful to focus on critiquing XR and their strategy - why not use the leverage you've gained via your own arrest and subsequent ordeal to write an article that lauds the fact that people are so moved by the issue of impending environmental collapse to put their time and bodies on the line? Use your power to highlight the main social justice and environmental issues that so badly need a different narrative to be told about them, and different ways of trying to achieve change, rather than attacking this group's strategy. 
I don't think it's clear any other approaches are particularly more effective than mass protest and mass arrests. So let's get behind them for what they're prepared to do! Making yourself arrestable is a big deal, a big statement. 
So, I say thank you to you, Ben, for putting your time and body on the line for an important cause, and to all those people gathering and being arrested today for their passion and dedication to struggle for a saner world.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555348932000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2153768', u'id': u'128095995', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Kavangh', u'text': u'I cannot think of something so bizarrely disconnected than expressing surprise about arrest and the process there of when you oppose the system itself.
What else would anyone expect? Systems are designed to protect and perpetuate themselves, if you rock you boat in any meaningful way you get the muscle.
Historically speaking, change has only come around from when the incumbent system buckles to spite it's efforts to oppress, not by meaningless toothless gestures that the ruling class have no motivation to care about becauseof their nature as pointless cowed, (largely) faux concern.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555350079000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17075231', u'id': u'128096449', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'BrotherLead', u'text': u'Quite.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555350069000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18196471', u'in_reply_to': u'128096334', u'id': u'128096447', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Jake  Choir', u'text': u'Smashing security doors etc isn't in my category of non-violent. Someone turned up with the tools, intent and effort to do that.', u'recommendation_count': u'21', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555349519000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100946850', u'in_reply_to': u'128094311', u'id': u'128096238', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PhilMcAvertie', u'text': u'I wonder how many of them were driven to somewhere near to the protest by mummy or daddy in their Chelsea tractor.', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555349518000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100489755', u'in_reply_to': u'128095729', u'id': u'128096237', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'michael4321', u'text': u'Middle class revolt feeling exited that they have rebelled for once in their life ha ha ha ,oh how they long to be working class to try feel the pain,,but given a dose they would scream blue murder and run a mile.', u'recommendation_count': u'32', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555350666000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11314488', u'id': u'128096685', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'Can you explain where we find the wackiness within climate science?
Thanks.', u'recommendation_count': u'28', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555348902000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'128095947', u'id': u'128095986', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'alanottoman', u'text': u'Heard on LBC one guy interviewed that had come from Rye. Wonder how he got to London?', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555348889000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16335884', u'in_reply_to': u'128094586', u'id': u'128095982', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Knowles2', u'text': u'so you could produce a functional electric car with 300 miles range in 1970s?
How about carbon capture technologies? were they really commercially viable back in 2000?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555350068000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3726027', u'in_reply_to': u'128096386', u'id': u'128096446', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'SayKnowToooSpelling', u'text': u'This comment was removed by a moderator because it didn't abide by our

For more detail see our FAQs.', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555349512000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"it did n't abide by our community standards", u'effect': u'this comment was removed by a moderator'}], u'author_id': u'2549069', u'id': u'128096233', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'jaymi555', u'text': u'They've just opened a massive new terminal with air travel set to double over the coming years.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555349501000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17063351', u'in_reply_to': u'128096062', u'id': u'128096223', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'zavaell', u'text': u'Louts? Do you know them or is this just your lazy use of insult?', u'recommendation_count': u'12', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555350650000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1347038', u'in_reply_to': u'128096542', u'id': u'128096680', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'BrexitHereWeCome', u'text': u'I was not talking about the cost of them.
I was talking about the thought process of someone who would buy 3 crates of water a week, when you can simply turn on the tap.', u'recommendation_count': u'23', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555350645000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16909885', u'in_reply_to': u'128096616', u'id': u'128096678', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GonePhishing', u'text': u'Where to start? Say 50.000 took part today in the UK (I'm guessing). How would it be possible to nick each and everyone? Also, given the well organised and publicised non violent, anti drug, booze, respect for the environment (not including building entrances or facades) or abuse of non participant passers by stance taken by the organisers, the only grounds for arrest is for obstruction, probably of a public highway. Enough numbers commit a really low level crime. Ghandi had tens of thousands march to the coast to collect sea water to make salt because the British had taxed an ancient right. They were joined by thousands more along the route, and it spread along the coast, many millions more across India followed suite with non violent protests;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salt_MarchThe British caved in, they simply didn't have the capacity or manpower to deal with it, despite arresting 60,000. The tax wasn't ended immediately, it was just impossible to collect it (ironically the British colonists were probably the only ones paying it) The Extinction Rebellion could have the same effect. But if 15 of them chain themselves to an airliner? Maximum fail, full force of the law.', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555348853000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the british had taxed an ancient right', u'effect': u'ghandi had tens of thousands march to the coast to collect sea water to make salt'}], u'author_id': u'13754880', u'in_reply_to': u'128094385', u'id': u'128095965', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Paysan', u'text': u'One thing we can all do is review our current lifestyles. Try to identify how we can personally reduce our carbon footprint. You could take a look at your family’s food and drink consumption over a period and review the source. If you do not already have one look at taking on an allotment possibly jointly. It is surprising how much fruit and veg is imported over vast distances. Look at your travel. Can you take a train, especially an electric one instead of taking the car or flying? I don’t think vandalism will achieve much. In my country of residence the high speed national electric rail network must save vast amounts of carbon.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555348851000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3086488', u'id': u'128095963', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'eddyt66', u'text': u'This will only affect them if the charge is upheld or if they accept a caution which they will not do if they have been trained properly.', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555350054000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1169173', u'in_reply_to': u'128094218', u'id': u'128096442', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'BrexitHereWeCome', u'text': u'"Then they will find that with a record jobs do not come easily."
Many of them look unemployable with our without a criminal conviction.', u'recommendation_count': u'22', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555350051000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16909885', u'in_reply_to': u'128096350', u'id': u'128096441', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'BitFick', u'text': u'Can't believe people are more angry with protestors causing a temporary interruption than a government who sits by whilst our habitat ebbs away!', u'recommendation_count': u'22', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555349495000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'protestors', u'effect': u'a temporary interruption than a government who sits by'}], u'author_id': u'101391025', u'id': u'128096221', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ZODIACKILLER', u'text': u'It’s great people are protesting, some countries you get shot. But for every protester, how many out shopping? I’m not hopeful this ends well. A few thousand protesters against not just government,corporations and consumers of which most of the protesters are. Many are at school, being taught that if they work hard, they’ll get a good job and earn money. There are already less jobs, there are already less opportunities. Education is based on a growth economy, growth needs to end for climate change to be affected. Environmental austerity, rationing, volunteering, no travel, no migration, it’s batten down the hatches time.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555349489000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12714597', u'id': u'128096220', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'CforCynic', u'text': u'BQSTART
We have all the tools, the skills, the technology and the money to transition to fossil free without all dying from the Black Death and St. Paul’s burning down ffs.
BQEND
Very true, but a 6 year timescale to do so is completely unrealistic - and I say that as someone who does a fair bit of work in the renewables sector.', u'recommendation_count': u'12', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555350641000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3949060', u'in_reply_to': u'128096388', u'id': u'128096677', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DisunitedKingdom', u'text': u'Bet you 50p?', u'recommendation_count': u'14', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555350633000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17239515', u'in_reply_to': u'128096593', u'id': u'128096674', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PeterMarkham', u'text': u'Stop the benefits and there would be no need.', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555348832000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12811742', u'in_reply_to': u'128095918', u'id': u'128095953', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Jeffd63', u'text': u'They will achieve nothing apart from alienating the vast majority of hard working Londoners.Why don't they form a political party and put their whacky ideas to the electorate.', u'recommendation_count': u'39', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555348810000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'101359318', u'id': u'128095947', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'RoxieCotton', u'text': u'Oh no, that won't do, they'd never consider taking their gap year in their own country!! Too many air miles to collect.', u'recommendation_count': u'29', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555350037000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'101375403', u'in_reply_to': u'128096301', u'id': u'128096435', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Paysan', u'text': u'They are also investing in rail', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555349912000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3086488', u'in_reply_to': u'128096223', u'id': u'128096396', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'thewhofan', u'text': u'The odd thing is that people who are conservative by politics watch the same programming on the BBC as you and see left wing biased media.
Perhaps the BBC is impartial and it's just your own expectation of how the BBC should behave that makes you think it's biased?', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555349488000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2596777', u'in_reply_to': u'128095735', u'id': u'128096219', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'whizz', u'text': u'Roger Hallam is almost certainly right that arrests are needed to force any meaningful response from UK society. However Ben Smoke makes valid points and it's only through mass arrests - really large numbers - including the young and very old that the government (and opposition parties - don't believe for one minute that any opposition party wants civil unrest when they are in power) will agree to take action. Politicians are under huge pressure already from commercial interests not to be swayed by civil action and all governments are totally driven by economic priorities. This fight will need more than a royal racehorse to move government and public opinion - just for example, in Cumbria a new coalmine has been given clearance to open backed by all the main political parties - there's a long way to go.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555349460000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2753506', u'id': u'128096206', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JudeScorpio', u'text': u'Rye-cycle...?', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555350630000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10270670', u'in_reply_to': u'128095982', u'id': u'128096673', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'realfilm', u'text': u'Couldn't have put it better myself! You have a hit a fundamental nail on the head.
And that is what XR needs to change - forget politics, and Westminster.. Appeal to the millions of "I'm alright Jack"ers.. 
Not at all sure that they will succeed ..', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555350617000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4349185', u'in_reply_to': u'128096477', u'id': u'128096667', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'alanottoman', u'text': u'And most of those were tourists wondering what all the fuss was about!', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555348772000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16335884', u'in_reply_to': u'128095080', u'id': u'128095935', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Tom Archer', u'text': u'I hope the police chuck the book at them and we get back to sorting out our arguments by debate and reason, rather than by criminality and intimidation.', u'recommendation_count': u'16', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555348758000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12103643', u'id': u'128095927', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'BrexitHereWeCome', u'text': u'This comment was removed by a moderator because it didn't abide by our
community standards.
Replies may also be deleted. For more detail see our FAQs.', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555349893000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"it did n't abide by our community standards", u'effect': u'this comment was removed by a moderator'}], u'author_id': u'16909885', u'id': u'128096389', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'paperninja', u'text': u'Oh for gods sake. It’s exactly that kind of ridiculous hyperbole that causes people to glue themselves to bloody doors. We have all the tools, the skills, the technology and the money to transition to fossil free without all dying from the Black Death and St. Paul’s burning down ffs.', u'recommendation_count': u'18', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555349882000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'that', u'effect': u'people to glue themselves to bloody doors'}], u'author_id': u'11739969', u'in_reply_to': u'128096320', u'id': u'128096388', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, ...]
description: As one of the Stansted 15, I know that dealing with arrests sucks vast amounts of time and money from the cause

og_fields.og:title: Extinction Rebellion protesters who want to be arrested: be careful what you wish for | Ben Smoke
text:
When I was arrested I did not hear most of the words of the police caution. I was being led from the front wheel of a deportation charter flight that I’d helped blockade at Stansted airport in March 2017. There were 15 of us in total, four around the wheel and 10 around a tripod behind the left wing. One of our number had been arrested before locking on. As an officer put handcuffs on me and walked me to the waiting bus, he started to arrest me. “I am arresting you on suspicion of aggravated trespass. You do not have to say anything – ”. When I rounded the corner, glimpsing the collection of my fellow activists, who I’d not seen since we’d cut through the fence many hours before, we all cheered, obscuring the words. Once I was arrested though, and sat alone in a police cell for hours on end, those cheers rang hollow. When we were released, and eventually charged with a terrorism-related offence – one carrying a maximum sentence of life imprisonment – that jubilance was replaced by endless worry, stress and pain.
We must be wary of glorifying arrests and incarceration as the only valid way of engaging with a movement
Today, and in the coming days, weeks and months, hundreds – perhaps thousands – of activists hope to be arrested. Some hope to go to prison. They are part of Extinction Rebellion, a group seeking urgent action on climate change in the 12 years we have left to avert cataclysmic ecological breakdown. As part of their International Rebellion, they are seeking to “shut down” areas of central London today for as long as possible to “disrupt the ‘business as usual’ which is sending our species on a one way track to extinction”.
These are laudable and righteous aims, ones that I agree with. There is no doubt in my mind that we need to move faster on climate change. Nor is there any doubt that most people would quite like to avoid a mass extinction event. Underneath it all, though, I can’t help but feel deeply concerned.
In a recent video for the Guardian, the founder of the group, Roger Hallam, tells a police officer that “arrests aren’t happening quickly enough”. Later, he’s seen telling a town hall meeting that “letters, emailing, marches don’t work. You need about 400 people to go to prison. About two to three thousand people to be arrested.” After a blood-pouring action outside Downing Street, protesters bemoaned the lack of arrests. In a recent article, one protester talks about giving up their training as a dancer to devote their full time to activism.
There’s undoubtedly something sexy about direct action. As activists we spend our life trying to agitate for change in a system built to resist it. Wins are rare, and the day-to-day grind of trying to transform the world into a better place – one that works for everyone – bears down on all of us. To take part in something material, that feels real, as if you’re actually doing something, is overwhelmingly attractive. But the reality is, direct action and becoming entombed in the endless bureaucracy of our glacial criminal justice system because of it, should make up only a tiny portion of our work as activists.
There is an inherent privilege in being able to be arrested for protesting. The hugely disproportionate number of BAME people in prisons for relatively minor offences shouldn’t be underestimated here. To have people like Roger Hallam speaking of prison so casually undermines those who are the poorest or most oppressed in our society whose lives are ripped apart by it.
There isn’t a day that goes by that I don’t feel guilty about our trial and subsequent conviction (no pun intended). Not because what we did was wrong – far from it. But because even though 11 people remain in Britain because of our action, the two years that followed the action saw an unfathomable amount of resources, time, money and energy from across the movement poured into helping us fight our case, to helping us stay afloat, and avoid a life incarcerated. It took valuable resources away from those at the sharp edges of the hostile environment that we were protesting about.
This is the issue with Extinction Rebellion’s ethos. The notion that 2,000 arrests will evoke the kind of systemic change needed to fight climate change is naive at best. At a time when the government has cracked down on protest, to not see that this could go the other way, and be used simply as a way of increasing already draconian anti-protest legislation and prosecutions, is shortsighted and irresponsible. But beyond that, the cost to individual activists, and the movement as a whole, would be huge.
That so many people are involved and excited about activism is great – but we must be wary of glorifying arrests and incarceration as the only valid way of engaging with a movement. A movement, particularly one seeking to change society as we know it, should not be a coterie of privileged activists who can afford the expense and time getting arrested. 
It should be about as many people as possible being brought on board. About making noise from all parts of society that’s so deafening, there is no option for those in power but to listen to our demands. It remains a mystery how wrapping up a whole new generation of activists in lengthy and costly court battles will achieve the changes we so urgently need.
• Ben Smoke is a freelance journalist and activist

article_tags: [Australia news, Australian politics, Tax, Health, Australian education, Australian economy, Australian universities, Climate change]
description: Grattan Institute’s Orange Book also finds a crisis of trust in politicians, risking undermining representative democracy
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Grattan Institute’s Orange Book also finds a crisis of trust in politicians, risking undermining representative democracy
og_fields.og:title: Australia behind similar countries in tackling homelessness and cost of living
text:
Compared with similar countries Australia is performing poorly when it comes to tackling homelessness and keeping cost of living down, and its electricity supply is more polluting, less reliable and more expensive.
These are some of the findings from the Grattan Institute’s Orange Book published on Tuesday night, which sets policy reform priorities for the next government and rates Australia’s performance in areas such as health, housing, education, and energy.
There is also a crisis of trust in politicians, the report says, which over time risked undermining representative democracy.
“Australian cynicism is now at an all time high ... Widespread loss of trust can make legislating policy change more complex, because it is harder for governments without political capital to enact ‘difficult but necessary’ reforms,” the report says.
“While there are many causes of falling trust and exasperation with the political establishment, one is the growing sense that people in government look after their own interests, or those of powerful groups, rather than the public interest.”
Grattan chief executive and lead author of the report John Daly said there were some positives, with retirement incomes generally sufficient [except for renters], and affordable health and education. But on many social issues, Australia rated poorly.
“These are evidence-based policy recommendations designed to serve the interests of all Australians rather than sectional interests,” Daly said.
The report says the next federal government should focus on tax reform, with some current tax arrangements “a big drag on economic growth”.
Income tax should be reduced, while welfare and childcare means tests should be modified to remove barriers and increase incentives for women and older people to participate in the workforce.
The report says that to pay for these changes and avoid other tax increases, the capital gains tax discount should be cut from 50% to 25%, while negative gearing should be wound back through quarantining wage and salary income so that passive investment losses can only be written off against other investment income. The GST should also be increased or broadened.
To increase workforce participation of older Australians, the report suggests investigating the costs and benefits of raising the pension age to 70.
Despite a push from various politicians for people to look beyond major cities and move to regional and rural areas, the Grattan Institute says the federal government should instead be lobbying the states to change planning laws to allow more medium-density housing in established suburbs.
“It is not that people will not move to the regions: they did so in large numbers when the mining investment boom presented attractive job opportunities. However, it seems that the living and employment conditions currently on offer in some regional areas are not attractive enough to Australians to induce more internal or overseas migrants.”
Carolyn Whitzman. a professor of urban planning at the university of Melbourne, said people would always prefer to live where jobs and opportunities were.
“The strong preference is always going to be for the central city and there is a certain lock-the-gate aspect, with lots of people moving into the cities and then saying ‘there’s no more room’.
“This issue isn’t a failure of immigration policy; it’s a failure of planning.”
The Orange Book calls for a universal dental care scheme, and a comprehensive review of the private health sector, including private health insurance.
It says rates of complications and questionable care in hospitals should be made public, a move also being called for by the Consumers Health Forum.
The report said pharmacists should be able to provide repeat prescriptions with the agreement of doctors and patients, and work with doctors to help patients manage chronic conditions. But it said overall, the health system was affordable and resulting in Australians living longer.
A health policy analyst with the Centre for Policy Development, Jennifer Doggett, said the Grattan report needed to be stronger on health equity.
“Yes, our health system performs well overall but the gap between those of us who get the best outcomes and those who miss out is huge. The gap between the life expectancy of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders and non-Indigenous people means that Indigenous Australians have a life expectancy less than that of people in North Korea,” she said.
“This is not just a health system problem but part of the solution needs to involve an explicit focus within the health system on addressing inequity.”
She said though the health system worked well “on paper” this was partly due to the uncounted time and resources that consumers and their carers were forced to contribute to coordinating and managing their care.
Doggett welcomed the call for powerful lobby groups to be held to account but said that would involve the government of the day taking on these groups. “It is not clear that either side of politics is prepared to do this,” she said.
The government must “finish the job” on school funding by reintroducing the demand-driven higher education system, and control costs by increasing repayment of HELP debt.
It also says entry into teaching should be made more prestigious, partly by pushing for prospective teachers to have an Atar (Australian tertiary admission rank) of about 80 or above. Prospective students should also be given more information about their chances of course completion, the report says. “Dis-enrol students who are not engaged with their studies so they don’t incur HELP debt.”
The deputy opposition leader Tanya Plibersek has said if universities did not move to lift standards, a Labor government would move to make Atar caps mandatory.
New school reform initiatives should be avoided unless evidence shows they are a good idea, and any government intervention should help and not hinder, the report said.
A co-author of the Grattan report, Dr Peter Goss, said over the course of decades the academic backgrounds of teachers had weakened.
“As a result of feminism women had more career choices so bright women were no longer pushed into teaching, which is great, but not good for schools,” Goss said.
“We’re concerned less about how do you cut off the lowest-ranked teachers, and much more concerned about how to send a signal to young people that education is a course for high achievers and career opportunities.”
The report calls for a code of conduct to be introduced for all parliamentarians on conflicts of interest. A Commonwealth Integrity Commission should be established to investigate corrupt and high-risk misconduct in the public sector, and investigate tip-offs.
“Cap expenditure on political advertising during election campaigns, and lower the donations disclosure threshold to $5,000,” the report says. “Require political parties to aggregate donations below the threshold, and introduce ‘real time’ disclosure of donations. Publish ministerial diaries.”
All lobbyists who enter parliament house should be subject to the Lobbying Code of Conduct, which should be enforced by criminal penalties, the report says.
The report urges the incoming government to develop a credible climate change policy.
“Our political leaders must be honest with voters: Australia needs to move to a low-emissions economy, and that transition will cost money,” the report says. “A raft of reforms to electricity generation, distribution and retailing are also required to push down energy costs.”
While economy-wide carbon price would be the best way to reduce emissions, in the absence of the political consensus needed to implement the best policy, “we should work with what we have,” it says.
“The work of the past two years means the incoming federal government, whether Coalition or Labor, will have the content and should have the political opportunity to introduce a stable and credible emissions reduction policy for the electricity sector. Reverting to subsidies and direct government funding would almost certainly be less effective and less efficient.”
The report did not examine Indigenous affairs, foreign affairs and trade, most immigration issues, defence and security, law and order, industrial relations, communications, agriculture, many welfare payments, or human services because they have not been part of Grattan’s research.

article_tags: [Australian election 2019, Australia news, Australian Greens, Australian politics, Labor party, Climate change, Environment, Sarah Hanson-Young, Adam Bandt]
description: Sarah Hanson-Young says party is not afraid to use its numbers in the Senate to push Bill Shorten to back key parts of its plans
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Sarah Hanson-Young says party is not afraid to use its numbers in the Senate to push Bill Shorten to back key parts of its plans
og_fields.og:title: Greens propose supporting Labor climate policy in environment deal
text:
The Greens will push Labor to back key parts of its new environment strategy – including a $2bn nature fund – in exchange for crucial support of the opposition’s climate change policy in the Senate.
Flagging the party’s readiness to negotiate over energy policy if Labor wins the election, the Greens senator Sarah Hanson-Young said the party was not afraid to use its numbers on the crossbench to extract stronger commitments from Bill Shorten on the environment.
The Labor leader has announced a baseline and credit scheme for polluters emitting more than 25,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide a year using the existing safeguard mechanism, but the party has also promised to provide concessions to trade-exposed heavy industries such as steel, aluminium and LNG.
The Greens, whose support may be critical for Labor to pass its climate policy through the Senate even if it wins a majority in the House of Representatives, say the scheme does not go far enough. It wants Labor to scrap plans to allow polluters to buy carbon credits from overseas, while also forcing them to pay for their damage to the environment.
The party is also pushing for a ban on all new coal mines, and wants existing approvals for the controversial Adani project reviewed.
The Greens climate change spokesman, Adam Bandt, has already expressed frustration with the shadow climate change spokesman, Mark Butler, who declared before the election was called the Australian parliament must end the current stalemate and back Labor’s climate policy in the event of a Shorten victory, otherwise politicians will betray the next generation. Bandt says Labor is in no position to issue ultimatums.
Hanson-Young, who is fighting to keep her South Australian Senate position at next month’s election, will unveil the Greens’ environment policy on Wednesday along with leader Richard Di Natale .
The centrepiece of the policy is the new nature fund, which would invest $2bn a year to protect Australian flora and fauna from invasive species, create new safe havens for threatened mammals and fund the development of recovery plans for at-risk species. The fund will also pay for 10,000 qualified “environment managers”, and boost the number of Indigenous rangers.
“In any negotiation with Labor over climate and the environment, we are going to be putting front and centre our extinction crisis and the need to protect and restore our environment,” Hanson-Young told Guardian Australia.
“What we are putting very clearly today is that this has to be part of the climate conversation.”
She said big polluters should be forced to invest in environmental programs because “they are the ones wrecking the joint”.
Hanson-Young said there was an expectation from voters that Labor’s environment policy was better than the Liberal party’s, but the opposition needed to come under more pressure to flesh out its plans.
“Really they haven’t been held to account over it at all yet; they have got no detail, they haven’t put any money on the table.”
At Labor’s national conference last year, Shorten committed to introducing a new environment act and creating a new commonwealth environmental protection authority after coming under pressure from the party’s Labor Environment Action Network, but is yet to provide details.
The Wilderness Society has called on the major parties and potential crossbenchers to commit to an overhaul of environmental protection laws and the establishment of new independent regulatory agencies before Australians cast their votes on 18 May.
Hanson-Young said the Greens in the Senate would “hold the Labor party to its promises on the environment”.
The Greens environment policy also proposes a new network of marine parks, including the Great Barrier Reef, and the outlawing of oil and gas exploration in the Great Australian Bight.

From Smeed et al, 2018:
Previous observations of the AMOC found a 0.6 Sv year−1 decrease over the period from 2007 to 2011 (Smeed et al., 2014). This is an order of magnitude larger than the long‐term forced trend predicted by Coupled Model Intercomparison Project Phase 5 coupled models (Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, 2013), and Smeed et al., (2014) concluded the observed changes were most likely caused by decadal change rather than a long‐term decline. A part of the change may be forced by anthropogenic warming, but the observational record is not yet long enough to separate long‐term forced changes from decadal‐scale internal variability...
...Our results show that the previously reported decline of the AMOC (Smeed et al., 2014) has been arrested, but the length of the observational record of the AMOC is still short relative to the time scales of important decadal variations that exist in the Atlantic. Understanding is therefore constantly evolving. What we identify as a changed state of the AMOC in this study may well prove to be part of a decadal oscillation superposed on a multidecadal cycle. Overlaying these oscillations is the impact of anthropogenic change that is predicted to weaken the AMOC over the next century. The continuation of measurements from the RAPID 26°N array and similar observations elsewhere in the Atlantic (Lozier et al., 2017; Meinen et al., 2013) will enable us to unravel and reveal the role of ocean circulation in the changing Atlantic climate in the coming decades.

Not only help warm, but also delivers significant humidity to the air... and spring rains.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555479398000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17691295', u'in_reply_to': u'128136931', u'id': u'128137608', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'And we have to decide soon, because impacts associated with sea level rise are likely to be more severe, and occur sooner than many expect. 
One problem with sea level rise is that the closer sea level approaches the top of a coastal defense, the greater the risk of a storm surge breaching the defense, as in New Orleans with Hurricane Katrina.
This means that many of our largest cities, being coastal, will likely go away swiftly in catastrophic storms rather than slowly with sea level rise.
There's only one narrow road leading out of the Florida Keys and it will be become a parking lot when people finally get scared by the strong hurricane rolling ashore.
We need to start adapting to the reality we've set in motion.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555477770000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'impacts associated with sea level rise are likely to be more severe and occur sooner than many expect', u'effect': u'and we have to decide soon'}], u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'128137142', u'id': u'128137257', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'Spring is springing faster. The summer bell curve has also shifted dramatically.
Migrating animals arrive after their food has appeared, or before the rains fell, because things are changing.
Farmers have long looked to the past for clues as to when grow our food. But that receding past is no longer a reliable indicator of what weather to expect.
There is no longer any "new normal"; we have a continually shifting climate to try to adapt to and that's a sticky problem.
Take sea level rise. Where do we relocate our large coastal cities, ports and naval facilities to? 10 meters above sea level? 20 meters? Compared to global temperature models which are based on clear physics our ice sheet models are rudimentary.
We don't know where to move them . . .', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555477174000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'things are changing', u'effect': u'migrating animals arrive after their food has appeared'}], u'author_id': u'15131989', u'id': u'128137142', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'Plants are part of short term carbon cycles. We are disrupting long term carbon cycles by burning fossil fuels laid down over hundreds of millions of years in a few hundred years.
And in case people haven't noticed the forests are already dying/burning at 1 degree C and we're likely headed for 3 or more.
Not even "super plants" are going to able to keep up with the fantastic rate and amplitude of change.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555476553000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'128130661', u'id': u'128137048', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'"what happens when the fish are no longer there?"
Atlantic fish stocks are between 1/1,000 and 1/10,000 of what they were just 150 years ago according to the Scripps Oceanographic marine ecologist emeritus Jeremy Jackson.
Here's a link to the transcript of a TED Talk by him worth watching, or reading, 
https://www.ted.com/talks/jeremy_jackson/transcript?language=en
The mass of the giant leatherback turtles of the Caribbean used to exceed that of the North American bison herds at their height.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555476330000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'128134750', u'id': u'128137011', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'"the gulf stream was at it's slowest in 1,600 yrs, some 15% slower..."
Surface waters of the ocean are warmer and hence less dense than waters at depth. So it takes a lot of energy to turn the ocean over. As the surface warms faster now than at depth it takes more energy to drive deep ocean circulation so the ocean gets more strongly stratified.
The flow of nutrient rich waters from the deep which feed great fisheries like the anchoveta slow, and oxygen rich surface waters slow their journey to the depths and the ocean turns to desert.
The loss of filter feeders and nitrogen from agricultural runoff create a dead-zonification of the coastal ocean.
And in a 2016 paper, James Hansen suggested that the shut down of deep ocean circulation was perhaps more sensitive to meltwater off of the ice sheets than the models have suggested.
"Winter of '17/18 was unusually cold and snowy in the UK"
The northern polar jet stream has been changing, perhaps due to Arctic ice decline, and this has slowed those winds, causing the jet stream to meander in wavy patterns which cause weather patterns to persist and bleed heat north and cold south.
Harvey's stall over Houston may have been influenced by the changes in the jet stream.
"gulf and Atlantic red tides in Florida"
When these tides hit shore and the breeze kicks the spray into the air hospitals in S Florida fill up with retirees with respiratory ailments.
In the past, hydrogen sulfide coming out the ocean was a suspected kill mechanism for several previous mass extinctions. 1
1. Any reason why this cannot be reversed and a Section 15 placed on Parliament because of the disruption they are causing by not doing anything?', u'recommendation_count': u'18', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555451518000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': None, u'effect': u'serious disruption'}, {u'cause': u'they', u'effect': None}, {u'cause': u'the disruption they are causing by not doing anything', u'effect': u'any reason why this can not be reversed and a section 15 placed on parliament'}], u'author_id': u'2700187', u'id': u'128130994', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'woodworm20', u'text': u'The earlier arrival of spring is part of a phenomenon known as season creep. It is one of the most notable effects of climate change. In one of the largest meta analyses in the field of phenology, involving 125,000 studies into 561 plant species....
Spring was beginning on average six to eight days earlier than it did 30 years ago, the researchers said.In regions such as Spain, which saw the greatest increases in temperatures, the season began up to two weeks earlier.The findings were based on what was described as the world's largest study of changes in recurring natural events, such as when plants flowered.The team of researchers also found that the onset of autumn has been delayed by an average of three days over the same period.The study, published in the journal Global Change Biology, shows changes to the continent's climate were shifting the timing of the seasons, the scientists said. One of the paper's lead authors, Tim Sparks from the UK's Centre for Ecology and Hydrology (CEH), said the findings did not go as far as pointing the finger of blame at human-induced climate change.
http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/5279390.stm', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1555451442000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11064682', u'id': u'128130959', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'catch18', u'text': u'In the light of things getting green and hopefully taking in C02 and letting go of H20 I'd like to offer an excellent article about the work of Dr. Joanne Chory. description: Flush of new beech leaves casts an early green glow across woodland floors
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Flush of new beech leaves casts an early green glow across woodland floors
og_fields.og:title: Plantwatch: leaves spring ever faster as temperatures rise
text:
A heavenly green spectacle is spreading northwards across the country as trees open their new leaves. The delicate green of tree leaves in spring is remarkable and perhaps the greatest spectacle is the flush of new beech leaves that are so translucent they cast a green glow across woodland floors.
This green colour comes from the chlorophyll pigment in the leaf chloroplasts, the tiny cell bodies that perform photosynthesis. As the young leaves are still developing their chloroplasts, the leaves tend to be a lighter green. The new leaves are also thinner, with fewer waxy or tough layers, making them more translucent. What’s more, the leaves look brighter because they tend to have fewer additional pigments other than chlorophyll, so the green colour can shine through more clearly. But this is only a passing phase before the leaves turn darker green as their chloroplasts mature and the leaves grow thicker and more opaque.
Another striking feature is how the trees in springtime have been tending to come into leaf earlier over recent decades, and that reflects how average spring temperatures across the UK have risen by about 1C over the last few decades. Spring even moves up the country faster for many plants and animals, averaging 1.2mph between 1891 and 1947, and 1.8mph between 1998 and 2014.
